Kar = Snow, c2002, Orhan Pamuk. Snow, is a novel by Turkish writer Orhan Pamuk. Published in Turkish in 2002, it was translated into English by Maureen Freely and published in 2004.. The story encapsulates many of the political and cultural tensions of modern Turkey and successfully combines humor, social commentary, mysticism, and a deep sympathy with its characters.. Ka is a poet, who returns to Turkey after 12 years of political exile in Germany. He has several motives, first, as a journalist, to investigate a spate of suicides but also in the hope of meeting a woman he used to know.. Heavy snow cuts off the town for about three days during which time Ka is in conversation with a former communist, a secularist, a fascist nationalist, a possible Islamic extremist, Islamic moderates, young Kurds, the military, the Secret Service, the police and in particular, an actor-revolutionary. In the midst of this, love and passion are to be found.. Temporarily closed off from the world, a farcical coup is staged and linked melodramatically to a stage play. A Autobiographical novel by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, first published in 1774.. Most of The Sorrows of Young Werther, a story about unrequited love, is presented as a collection of letters written by Werther, a young artist of a sensitive and passionate temperament, to his friend Wilhelm.. These give an intimate account of his stay in the fictional village of Wahlheim (based on Garbenheim, near Wetzlar), whose peasants have enchanted him with their simple ways.. Spoiler Alert. There he meets Charlotte, a beautiful young girl who takes care of her siblings after the death of their mother. Werther falls in love with Charlotte despite knowing beforehand that she is engaged to a man named Albert, eleven years her senior.. Despite the pain it causes him, Werther spends the next few months cultivating a close friendship with them both. His sorrow eventually becomes so unsupportable that he is forced to leave Wahlheim for Weimar, where he makes the acquaintance of Frรคulein von B. He suffers great embarrassment when he forgetfully visits a friend and unexpectedly has to face there the weekly gathering of the entire aristocratic set.. He is not tolerated and asked to leave since he is not a nobleman. He then returns to Wahlheim, where he suffers still more than before, partly because Charlotte and Albert are now married. Every day becomes a torturing reminder that Charlotte will never be able to requite his love.. She, out of pity for her friend and respect for her husband, decides that Werther must not visit her so frequently. He visits her one final time, and they are both overcome with emotion after he recites to her a passage of his own translation of Ossian.. Even before that incident, Werther had hinted at the idea that one member of the love triangle โ Charlotte, Albert or Werther himself โ had to die to resolve the situation. Unable to hurt anyone else or seriously consider murder, Werther sees no other choice but to take his own life.. After composing a farewell letter to be found after his death, he writes to Albert asking for his two pistols, on the pretext that he is going "on a journey".. Charlotte receives the request with great emotion and sends the pistols. Werther then shoots himself in the head, but does not die until twelve hours later. He is buried between two lime trees that he had mentioned frequently in his letters. The funeral is not attended by any clergy, or by Albert or Charlotte. One of the best books of the author and probably the most well-known. I do not know where this popularity is due to but I can make the assumption that it is due to the fact that it is the most accessible of his great works, the one which the author's purpose is clearer, with that not meaning that it is a complex work, containing many more messages than are visible at first glance. But the basic message of human suffering and the possibility of correcting society through instinctive goodness and not by supposed revolutionary ideologies, by emotion and not by logic is clear, and the author gives it to the reader in the most staggering way.. As most people know, the story of this book starts with a murder, not something unusual, but because obviously we are not talking about a police story, the sequel is different. The killer and protagonist of the story believe that behind his act there are noble motives that can justify or, even more so, turn it into a heroic act that can become the starting point for a better life for many tortured people. Things, however, do not go as planned and because, in reality, he is not a bad person who could hurt someone without having any consciousness trouble, doubts start from the first moment and end in many days of reflection as he continues his life in most poor areas of St. Petersburg.. However, confronting this situation with the unhappy people living on the margins of survival in miserable homes, daily sacrificing their dignity to make a little money, finding a way out in alcohol, while the action of the most immoral people continues unabated while society in general shows the greatest indifference, the justification of his action becomes more powerful. Unable to overcome his selfishness he still believes that he simply got rid of a social parasite and thus offered something to people. This wall, however, is slowly breaking down as he associates with ordinary people who are truly sorry for this situation and by altruism sacrificing themselves without waiting for rewards. In front of these people who do not have the great theories and great ideas, that are simply driven by their Christian perceptions - which he so despises - this intellectual feels small and his complex analyzes and his determination to act accordingly to an unmistakable logical plan look like nothing more than manifestations of selfishness and arrogance. At the same time, the rope tightens around him and all that weight is growing, so the author takes us by the hand and leads us to ever more intense moments to the redemption finale.. What has made it difficult is the story that narrates which is seemingly simple, like a fairy tale, but it hides more in it. I loved it very much at first, I felt really enchanted, but then it was difficult to follow it, somewhere I found it confused, somewhere indifferent, and the multitude of events and of the leading characters it contained was enough to cause me fatigue. Above all, however, the fact that this story is essentially an allegory of the history of Latin America, with the events that marked this region of the planet, but also with the mentality of its inhabitants, their perceptions and obsessions, adds a particular weight for the reader, especially if he has an idea of this history.. Of course this difficulty does not mean that I was not aware of what I was reading or that it made me question the value of the book, quite the opposite, and this appreciation was increasing as I realized that the author wanted to say a lot and he did that through the pages he wrote. At some point, this becomes clear to the reader as historical references, with the coups, the interventions of foreign powers, political violence and everything that has plagued these peoples, as well as the social changes brought about by new technologies and new ideas, upsetting but also often reinforcing traditional perceptions. The village where history unfolds serves the writer to create a miniature of Latin America and this condensation of space is followed by the condensation of time, and so in not so many pages we have virtually everything. Men and women, typical cases of Latin American people, symbols but above all people who had the luck or the misfortune to live in a region of violence, ugliness but also of miracles..
